prompt.text: Hi, [NAME].
Nice to meet you, [NAME].
Howdy, [NAME]!
Hello, [NAME]!
Welcome! We'll be starting shortly.
Welcome! We'll be starting in just a moment.
Welcome to the Diamond Kata exercise! We'll be starting shortly.
Hi! Nice to see you. We're going to do the Diamond Kata exercise.
Nice to see you! I'm Agent Rachel. Please take a moment to introduce yourselves.
First, please take a minute to introduce yourselves.
Nice to see you! I'm [AGENT NAME]. Please take a moment to introduce yourselves.
Again, welcome! Please take a minute to introduce yourselves.
Hello again, you two! Do you know each other?
Greetings! Please share your names and one thing you like about this course.
I'm [AGENT NAME]. Please share your names.
Today, we'll practice pair programming as you collaborate on the Diamond Kata exercise. We'll use test-driven development.
When you've reached your seats, you can start on the first test case.
Go ahead and take your positions as Driver and Navigator.
It is time for us to wrap up now. It has been a pleasure working with you. The activity is now over.|Have a nice day!
Navigator::You've passed a test case for the number of lines your program will output. Do you need to know the number of output lines? Please discuss.
Navigator::You've passed a test case for the number of lines your program will output. Next, work on positioning each letter within a line.
Navigator::You've passed another test case. Next, we'll work on producing the upper half of the diamond.
Navigator::You've passed yet another test case. For the final case, we'll work on producing a complete diamond.
Navigator::You've passed all the test cases! Would you code any of your solution differently if you did it again?
It's time to move on.
Driver::For the first test case, [NAME1], start as the Driver. If someone joins you later, they will be the Navigator.
Driver::For the first test case, [NAME1] will be the [ROLE1] and [NAME2] will be the [ROLE2].
Driver::For the first test case, [NAME1] will be the [ROLE1] and [NAME2] will be the [ROLE2].
Driver::For the first test case, [NAME1] will be the [ROLE1] and [NAME2] will be the [ROLE2].
For the next test case, [NAME1] will be the [ROLE1]. If someone joins you later, they will be the Navigator.
For the next test case, [NAME1] will be the [ROLE1] and [NAME2] will be the [ROLE2].
For the next test case, [NAME1] will be the [ROLE1] and [NAME2] will be the [ROLE2].
For the next test case, [NAME1] will be the [ROLE1] and [NAME2] will be the [ROLE2].
As you move about the room, remember to stay at least 6 feet apart for social-distancing.
As you move about the room, remember to stay at least 6 feet apart for social-distancing.
While I won't tell you answers directly, I can help guide the group' discussion.
Once you get an idea of what's going on, replace these prompts with something domain appropriate!
I will share images to the whiteboard to help/guide you

The agent is listening for several kinds of triggers to start supporting students. |For example, David cares a lot about "Accountable Talk" style facilitation these days. | The provided AT example is configured for college chemistry. If you've turned on any of the revoice, agree, say_more, or explain conditions, try saying something like "boiling point increases with dipole moment."|(and then wait a little while, this behavior waits for other students to follow up before offering support.)
Now I'll start an interactive dialogue.
Welcome! I'm [AGENT NAME]. I'm here to have an interactive dialogue with you to assist you in your programming task.
Note that other agent behaviors (like accountable-talk style listening) will be suppressed while the dialogue is underway.
